So what going on inside the battery is a shorting of the negative and positive "plates" which is causing it to heat up.  The plates inside all batteries need to be kept wet which is   sulfuric acid, the wet substance leaking out.  It's not normally dark like that.  The dark grey is from the lead plates being broken mixing with the acid.  This battery is a 1.5v.  Pure sulfuric acid has a specific gravity of 1835.  With an industrial forklift battery each cells s.g. should be at 1260- 1300 which would equal 2.10v- 2.14v per cell.  I'd say these batteries have a 1210-1230 s.g.  So yeah, and sulfuric acid is a dry liquid, which means it activates with water or any wet substance.  So if you have a bucket of pure 1800 sulfuric acid and you toss a small cup of water in the bucket.  You'll get a explosion with acid spraying everywhere and a cloud  of smoke.  And if have a cut it'll activate with bodily fluids and burn.

Imagine if it was possible anyway, a new 9v PP3 battery was invented the SUPERCURRENT DURACELL and was released on the market, the big difference is that the fault level at the terminals exceeded 10,000Amps not just tiny 2 Amps and stored a ridiculous 1MegaWatt hour..but still at only 9V DC, you can then imagine the massive explosion and arc blast if one short circuited the battery, it would be lethal, and hence why these batteries are absolutely gutless.

As you can see the batteries are fairly harmless. They do not have enough power output, or discharge current to be dangerous and the chemical reactions are slow. hence no massive explosions. Not all batteries are this well behaved, and as battery technology improves and batteries gain more capacity and higher discharge current capability. Such as Lithium ion rechargeable batteries the results can be explosive and dangerous.

Then there is the rechargeable batteries which are always sketchy to mess with as they are the ones to explode on you. After the initial "POP" they are more or less done but rechargeable can burn and keep burning well after. There are some chemical batteries that do not recharge that can explode and be very deadly but those are not the type of batteries that most people use in remote controls.

When the lithium sheets burned, I think they were reacting to the firebrick to form Lithium Aluminate (LiAlO2) and Lithium Metasilicate (Li2SiO3) because the firebrick is composed of up to 50-80% Aluminum Oxide and the rest are silica (a form of silicon) so here's what I think is happening:
4Li+Al2O3+3SiO2--Heat->LiAl2+3Li2SiO3
And some other reactions creating other byproducts like the escaping gasses and stuff that you can't really figure out with just some video footage. (the equation is balanced so no need to correct me in the replies)

Two different metals and electrolytes which matches their metal for instance Fe rod inside an Fe 3+ electrolyte and a Cu rod inside a Cu 2+ electrolyte. The electrolytes are usually in paste form. To educatw these across the pond,

Sir Humphry Davy made a bit of a mess of naming this new element, at first spelling it alumium (this was in 1807) then changing it to aluminum, and finally settling on aluminium in 1812. His classically educated scientific colleagues preferred aluminium right from the start, because it had more of a classical ring, and chimed harmoniously with many other elements whose names ended in -ium, like potassium, sodium, and magnesium, all of which had been named by Davy.

This is hard to watch someone using the IR thermometer incorrectly.   Cool experiment, but the IR thermometer measures a spot that increases the further you are away.   So to get an accurate measurement, you have know the size of the target cone (usually printed on the side).  Also, some surfaces are completely a mirror in the IR spectrum.   If you ever get a chance, use the Flir or Seek infrared camera dongles ($200 to $250) on a phone.   The thermal camera lets you see the temperature pixel by pixel.   You can also compare the IR thermometer with the camera and get a better idea how to use it properly.  It is also easy to see surfaces that are mirrors in the IR spectrum.

Alkaline batteries aren't going to react that much, as we saw. The components that are used are manganese oxide (positive terminal or cathode) and zinc (negative terminal or anode). I believe these chemicals, though I'm no chemist and certainly did not do well in chemistry, does not generally have in explosive results. I think the real dangers with batteries comes in when you start playing around with modern Lithium and NiMH batteries. I've seen videos where someone stabbed such a battery with a nail and it literally started blasting fire like a firework almost immediately. This is also the type of battery that was causing Samsung such heartache with its Galaxy Note 7 product.
